name: Host-Sees-Guest-Perspective Card
description: A cross-journey card that shows the host what the guest sees about their listing and property. Includes the guest's view of the listing photos, the cleaning protocol, and the house manual. Allows the host to preview the guest experience from their own dashboard, building empathy and reducing anxiety about what guests are being shown. Fills the 'cross-journey elements' gap — host seeing guest's perspective.
fills_gap: Cross-journey elements — host seeing guest's perspective

behavioral_notes: Tabs switch views between Listing, House Manual, and Reviews perspectives. 'Visible/Partial/Hidden' badges show exactly what guests can see at each stage. The 'Edit' link takes the host to the relevant section. This card evolves ds-ui-1000-003 (status-first dashboard) by adding a perspective-switching dimension, combines ds-ui-0801-004 (Stays Manager) guest-facing data with the host view, and extends ds-ui-0800-002 (Protection Shield) by showing the guest-facing version of verification.
emotional_intent: Control and transparency. The host should feel 'I know exactly what my tenants are seeing about my apartment, and I can change anything I don't like.' This directly addresses Dimitri's third-party skepticism by making the platform transparent.
test_criteria: 70%+ of hosts who view this card report feeling 'in control' of their listing presentation. 25%+ of hosts edit their listing after seeing the guest perspective. Time spent on the card: under 30 seconds.

name: Micro-Review Prompt Card
description: A one-tap micro-review card that appears on the host dashboard after each guest stay. Instead of a traditional post-lease review, this captures a quick thumbs-up/thumbs-down plus one optional sentence after EACH stay. Over a 12-week lease, this accumulates 12 micro-reviews into a temporal narrative. Fills the 'review/rating UI' gap. Compounds on the space care photo streak concept from ds-ui-1001-005 by applying the same habit-loop principle to reviews.
fills_gap: Review/rating UI — no micro-review or rating elements exist yet
html_css:
A

How was Ariel's stay?

Stay #4 of 12 · Checked out Thursday

Quick check: how did this week go at 30th Street?
3 of 12 stays reviewed
behavioral_notes: Appears on the host dashboard within 24 hours of guest checkout. One-tap response (thumbs up or 'something to note'). Optional text field for details. The streak dots (3/12 stays reviewed) create the same habit-loop as ds-ui-1001-005's space care streak. Over time, 12 micro-reviews create a temporal narrative more valuable than a single post-lease review. For remote hosts like Dimitri, this is the weekly engagement touchpoint from Europe.
emotional_intent: Low-effort engagement. The host should feel 'this takes 5 seconds and helps me track how things are going from overseas.' The streak visual provides accumulating evidence of a successful lease.
test_criteria: Micro-review completion rate above 70% per stay. Average time to complete under 15 seconds. Hosts who micro-review show 30%+ higher retention than those who don't.

name: In-Platform Chat Thread with Agent Context
description: A messaging thread between host and guest with the agent (Bryant) as a visible third participant. Messages from the agent are visually distinguished. The host can toggle between 'direct to guest' and 'through agent' messaging modes. Fills the 'messaging/communication UI' gap. Compounds on the agent trust bridge concept by making the agent present in digital communication, not just initial onboarding.
fills_gap: Messaging/communication UI — no in-platform chat elements

behavioral_notes: Three-party chat with agent as a visible but non-intrusive participant. Agent messages use dashed-border styling to distinguish from direct host-guest messages. The 'Direct/Via Bryant' toggle lets the host choose whether to message the guest directly or route through the agent. Timezone display in message timestamps helps overseas hosts. This evolves ds-ui-0800-003 (Agent Welcome Bridge) from a one-time card into a persistent communication channel, and extends ds-ui-1000-006 (Patient Follow-Up Email) from async email into real-time chat.
emotional_intent: Control with backup. The host should feel 'I can talk to my tenant directly, but Bryant is right here if I need him.' This directly addresses Dimitri's 'I usually deal directly' preference while maintaining the platform's value.
test_criteria: 60%+ of hosts use in-platform chat vs. off-platform communication. Agent-mediated messages resolve issues 2x faster than direct messages. Chat engagement correlates with 20%+ higher deal completion rate.

name: Guest Arrival House Manual Card
description: A mobile-first house manual card that appears in the guest's Stays Manager on their arrival day. Shows key move-in information: lockbox code, Wi-Fi password, house rules, emergency contacts, and neighborhood essentials. Collapsible sections with icons. The host creates this once and it's shown to every guest automatically. Fills the 'house manual / move-in checklist' gap.
fills_gap: House manual / move-in checklist — no guest onboarding elements for arrival

name: Host Notification Escalation Timeline
description: A notification preference panel that lets the host configure escalation levels for different event types. Three tiers: Silent (in weekly digest only), Normal (push notification during daytime), Urgent (immediate push any time). Pre-configured defaults for remote hosts with timezone detection. Fills the 'guest-side notifications' gap by also showing what notifications the guest receives. Compounds on the timezone-aware notification pattern from this run's behaves-003.
fills_gap: Guest-side notifications — notification escalation exists for hosts only; this adds guest notification visibility

name: Weekly Calendar Strip with Stay Visualization
description: A horizontal weekly calendar strip that shows the current and next 4 weeks of the lease. Each day is a small cell colored by state: guest-present (purple fill), guest-absent (gray), exception-modified (dashed outline), today (ring highlight). Replaces the pure card-based approach with a temporal view. Fills the 'calendar/scheduling views' gap — everything in the library is card-based, no calendar.

Compounds on the agent trust bridge, status-first dashboard, and listing import patterns.
